Reno LPG Terminal
Kiva Energy, LP Terminal, LLC
Executive Summary
Risk Management Plan
EPA Identifier:  1000 0018 5738

FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY
The owners, management, and employees of Kiva Energy - LP Terminal, LLC Reno (Reno Terminal) located at 19975 Reno Park Blvd, Reno, Nevada in Washoe County, are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of odorized, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG, propane). Kiva Energy contracted with WSP USA Environment and Infrastructure, Inc. (WSP USA) to develop a program to comply with the requirements of the U.S. EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) Regulation and the Nevada State Chemical Accident Prevention Program (CAPP). The Reno Terminal is covered by the Federal EPA RMP Rule, 40 CFR Part 68, and utilizes the inventory data, offsite consequence analysis, population estimates and other information contained the RMP Registration for compliance with the requirements of the State of Nevada Administrative Code (NAC) CAPP, NAC Sections 459,95321 through 459.9533 and NAC Sections 459.95348 through 459.95376.

If an accidental release should occur, the facility staff are prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Emergency Response Plan has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.

FACILITY INFORMATION

The Facility is a bulk, hydrocarbon storage and handling facility that receives LPG by rail cars and trucks. The LPG is stored in the facility's aboveground, storage tanks (pressure vessels) prior to being loaded into U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT)-approved delivery trucks (owned by Kiva Energy as well as third-party distributors). The three pressure vessels (PV17.01, PV17.02, and PV17.03) are manifolded (i.e., interconnected) and are operated as a single storage unit.

A propane compressor (vapor) is used to create a pressure differential betwee

n the rail cars or trucks being unloaded and the receiving vessels. The differential pressure "pushes" the LPG from the tank cars or trucks into the storage vessels. 

The propane stored in the three, 30,000-gallon, aboveground propane storage pressure vessels (see details below) is transferred to DOT-approved, LPG transportation trucks. Propane is transferred from the storage vessels to the delivery trucks by way of a liquid propane pump. Tanker truck capacity ranges from approximately 10,000 gallons (transport trucks) to 3,000 gallons (or less) for the bobtail-style, local delivery trucks. 

The storage vessels are equipped with excess flow valves. The vessels are also protected by a manually-actuated, emergency shutdown system. The emergency shutdown system has been designed to provide a means to rapidly shut down equipment and to place the facility in a safe condition as quickly as possible in order to minimize the possibility of a catastrophic occurrence.

The Reno Terminal limits the volume of propane in the storage vessels to no more than 85% of the shell capacity. Propane, as a liquefied, compressed gas, has a density of 4.22 lbs per gallon. The net and aggregate volumes of storage vessels are as follows: 

Vessel                        Vessel Capacity     Maximum Volume     Amount of Propane 
PV17.01-PV17.03           30,000 gals         25,500 gals            107,610 lbs
Net PV17.01-PV17.03       90,000 gals         76,500 gals            322,830 lbs

Totals                     90,000 gals         76,500 gals            322,830 lbs

The maximum amount of propane present within the interconnected storage vessels is 322,830 lbs. This number represents that volume contained in the 3 storage pressure vessels (as described above). 

The Reno Terminal is served by a rail siding. The rail siding is equipped with a derail to prevent cars from entering the adjacent rail line and to prevent cars from the adjacent rail line from entering the siding. The railcars are

spotted by the railroad. The siding has capacity for up to five (5) railcars. The data regarding the railcars on the siding are as follows: 

DOT Railcar             Vessel Capacity     Maximum Volume     Amount of Propane
Railcar (on siding)         34,500 gals       29,325 gals        123,752 lbs

Railcars (5) Total          172,500 gals      146,625 gals       618,758 lbs

The maximum amount of propane contained in the 5 DOT railcars on the Reno Terminal's siding is 618,758 lbs. That number represents that volume present in the DOT Type 105, 112, or 114 rail cars.

The maximum amount of propane on site is 223,125 gallons (stationary vessels and railcars on the siding). That volume of propane has a weight of 941,588 lbs. 

THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO
The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario were evaluated for each of the regulated processes. The detailed results of the evaluation are provided in the Risk Management Plan (RMP). Administrative controls limit the tank fill capacity to in accordance with National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) 58 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code, Section 7.4.3.2(B).

Worst-Case Release Scenario:  The worst-case release scenario is the release of propane from three (3) storage pressure vessels when filled to the greatest amount. The scenario assumes a complete release of 322,830 pounds of propane gas. The pressure wave (with an endpoint of 1 pound per square inch gauge over atmospheric pressure) would extend 0.6 miles (0.96 kilometers). The pressure wave could reach nearby industrial business located to the north of the site and an electrical substation west of the site. There are residences within the affected zone. There are environmental receptors within the affected zone.

Alternative Release Scenario:  The alternative release scenario based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident) is a catastrophic release from a full-sized (10,000 gallon water c

apacity), tanker truck. This scenario assumes that the tanker leaks from the bottom mounted entry valve and that the entire contents of the truck are released to the atmosphere. The alternative release scenario would produce a pressure wave with an endpoint of 1 pound per square inch gauge over atmospheric pressure that would extend 0.2 miles (0.3 kilometers). The resulting pressure wave has the potential to impact nearby businesses within this radius. There are residences within the affected zone. There are environmental receptors within the affected zone.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.

Safety Information:  Kiva Energy keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain a safe operating process. These documents address chemical properties. Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure. Treatment considerations is provided in safety data sheets (SDS's).

Kiva Energy also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the safe normal operations and emergency shutdown of the process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure ratings, temperature ratings and electrical rating of equipment.

Hazard Review:  Kiva Energy conducted a hazard review of the operations at the Reno Terminal. The hazard review employed the Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOPS) methodology and a Checklist method analysis. The plant operator and operations management identified and evaluated hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and the team made recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.

Operating Procedures:  The Reno Terminal maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations such as:
(1) start-up, 
(2) normal operations, 
(3) temporary operations, 
(

4) emergency shutdown, 
(5) normal shutdown, and 
(6) initial startup of a new process. 

These procedures provide guidance for experienced operators and also provide the basis for training new operators. Operating procedures include applicable safety precautions that must be taken in the operation of the facility. The procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. The review and certification process involves both operators and technical staff. 

Training:  The Reno Terminal facility staff, and Kiva Energy corporate staff, understand that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program. The Reno Terminal has a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the process equipment. 

The training program is comprised of the following:

- Initial employee training;
- Periodic refresher training (provided at least every three years);
- Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification;
- Competency testing involving written tests and observation following training; and
- Training records for each employee.

Maintenance & Mechanical Integrity:  The maintenance program at the Reno Terminal is intended to preserve the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to minimize the potential for an accidental release. The Reno Terminal has well established practices and procedures for maintaining process equipment. The basic aspects of this program include (1) training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting equipment deficiencies. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process. Equipment inspections are conducted on a monthly or quarterly basis. The freq

uency of the inspection is based upon regulatory framework impacting the particular system or subsystem. 

Management of Change:  The Kiva Energy Reno Terminal employs a change management system that requires changes to various systems or items, such as process equipment, technology, procedures and other facility functions, be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. This program ensures that the safety of the facility is not compromised by the change. Operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on any changes as part of the change management process.

Pre-startup Safety Review:  The Reno Terminal conducts a pre-startup safety review prior to the operating equipment or systems following a modification that requires a change in process safety information. The purpose of the pre-startup safety review is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment in service. 

Compliance Audits:  Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years. Plant operations and management personnel participate as audit team members. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to operations or facility management for resolution.

Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. 

Incident Investigation:  The Reno Terminal has procedures in place that require prompt investigation of incidents that resulted in or could have reasonably resulted in, a fire/explosion, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendation(s) to prevent a recurrence and presents these results to the business management team for resolution. 

Employee Participation:  The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and discip

8 - Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code; 2020 edition; 
- NFPA 70 - National Electrical Code; 
- RMA Standard Number M-5;
- United States Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA) 48 CFR 68; and 
- United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.110, Storage and Handling of Liquefied Petroleum Gases.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Over the past five years there have been no large or small releases which have resulted in any injuries, property damage or offsite consequences. An incident investigation program is in place at the Facility and incident investigations would be implemented if needed. 

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Reno Terminal maintains a written emergency procedure, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The procedures describe the manner of response to a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs. Employees receive training in emergency procedures.

The overall emergency procedure program for the Reno Terminal is coordinated with the Washoe County Emergency Management & Homeland Security Program. This coordination involves periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials and industry representatives. The Reno Terminal has around the clock communications capability with appropriate Emergency Management Program officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., Reno Fire Department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. The facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with NAC Sections 459.9544 and 459.95442.
 
The emergency response program is updated in when necessary based on modifications made to the plant facilities. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Safety impr

ovement is an on-going process at the Reno Terminal. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the propane process at the Reno Terminal will be implemented as needed.
